Award.AwardTitle: Single Photon Emission by Atomic Ensembles: Collective, Virtual and Non-Local Effects
Award.AbstractNarration:
The collective nature of light emission by many atoms can yield radiation speedup or light trapping even if a single photon is stored in the atomic cloud. This project will investigate how emission and absorption of virtual photons occurring on a very short time scale, and retardation caused by the finite value of the speed of light, affect emission of electromagnetic radiation by atomic systems. The influence of those effects on evolution of fast and slow decaying collective states will be calculated for various shapes of the atomic cloud. Quantum features of photon emission by atomic ensembles and interplay between superradiant and stimulated processes will be investigated. The project will advance the understanding of collective interaction between light and atoms at the quantum single-photon level, and it will yield deeper insights into quantum electrodynamics in general.

This project could have important practical implications beyond the intellectual interest. The research can be useful in various applications of the entangled atomic ensembles and the generated quantum states of light, for optical quantum-state storage, quantum cryptography, quantum communication and quantum information. The program will involve education and training of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers and will give them an opportunity to work on problems which lie at the interface of modern quantum optics and many body physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collective nature of light emission by many atoms can yield superradiant radiation speedup or light trapping even if a single photon is stored in the atomic cloud. A laser generates light through stimulated emission of radiation by atoms or molecules and requires population inversion. Quantum interference can yield lasing without inversion which still requires some atomic population in the excited state. Work on the project yielded a discovery of a new mechanism of light amplification by superradiant emission of radiation which does not need atomic population in the excited state.  We call a device that operates by such a principle the QASER which stands for Quantum Amplification by Superradiant Emission of Radiation. The amplification mechanism of the QASER is governed by the difference combination parametric resonance which occurs when the driving field frequency matches the frequency difference between two close high frequency normal modes of the coupled light-atom system. The resulting superradiant amplifier is many orders of magnitude more efficient than the usual nonlinear multiphoton excitation and holds promise for a new kind of generator of high-frequency (XUV or X-ray) coherent radiation. We found a physically appealing explanation of the QASER operation in terms of coupled classical oscillators and presented an experiment which demonstrates the QASER amplification mechanism in the radio frequency range in electronic circuit and in a system of two coupled microwave cavities.   

We demonstrated the possibility of generation of coherent radiation with tunable frequencies higher than the frequency of the driving field in a nonlinear medium with negative refractive index or materials with strong anomalous dispersion utilizing the QASER mechanism. Our discovery of the difference combination resonance in such materials opens a perspective for development of a new kind of coherent light source of tunable wavelengths which generates light with frequency higher than those of the driving field.

We studied interaction of γ-rays with a coherently vibrating periodic array of nuclei and demonstrated that combination of superradiance, Bragg diffraction and parametric resonance can be used for fast manipulation of the γ-ray propagation through crystals on short superradiant time scale which can potentially result in development of γ-ray mirrors and switches.

It has been known for two decades that coherence can yield lasing without inversion, which could be useful for making lasers at shorter wavelength. However, excitation of extreme ultraviolet and x-ray atomic transitions typically requires a plasma medium with rapid collisions, which destroy atomic coherence. We found that superradiance can assist conventional lasing on a short time scale smaller than collisional decoherence and yield lasing without inversion in transient regime.

Project involved comparison between fully quantum mechanical and semiclassical descriptions of interaction of light and atomic ensembles. A fully quantum mechanical treatment of this problem is usually very complicated mathematically. We showed, however, that quantum mechanical evolution equations describing single photon emission (absorption) by atomic ensembles can be written in a form equivalent to the semiclassical Maxwell-Bloch equations. Thus, mathematically challenging problem of single-photon superradiance can be reduced to solution of relatively simple differential equations. Based on this connection, we found new exact analytical solutions of the fully quantum mechanical problem. We also found that semiclassical Maxwell-Bloch equations must be written in a form different from those commonly used.
